articleContent.title: Chord: 13th in A (Shape: E)
articleContent.content:
# Chord: 13th in A (Shape: E)

## Brief Description:
The A 13th chord played in the form of an E shape on the guitar is a rich and complex chord voicing that adds color and tension to a progression. It consists of the root note A, major third C#, perfect fifth E, dominant seventh G, major ninth B, perfect eleventh D, and thirteenth F#. This chord form is commonly used in jazz and other genres to create a sense of richness and sophistication.

## Notes and Intervals:
- Root (1): A
- Major Third (3): C#
- Perfect Fifth (5): E
- Dominant Seventh (b7): G
- Major Ninth (9): B
- Perfect Eleventh (11): D
- Thirteenth (13): F#

## Musical Flavor:
The A 13th chord in the E shape brings a luxurious and sophisticated sound to a progression. With its mix of tension and resolution notes, such as the major third and dominant seventh, the chord creates a harmonically rich texture. Its extended nature makes it perfect for adding complexity and color to jazz, funk, and R&B compositions.

## Songs:
1. **"So What" by Miles Davis**: This jazz standard features many 13th chords, including the A 13th in E shape, adding to the modal sound of the piece.
   
2. **"I Wish" by Stevie Wonder**: In this funky tune, the A 13th chord in E shape is used to create a groovy and sophisticated harmonic foundation.

3. **"Chameleon" by Herbie Hancock**: This jazz-funk classic uses extended chords like the A 13th in E shape to build a complex and exciting harmonic backdrop.
